title: Global Zooplankton Biomass Distribution
text: This paper can be found here as well as the corresponding github repository.

title: Global Zooplankton Biomass Distribution
text:
Study Overview

We used in situ imaging data from the Underwater Vision Profiler 5 (UVP5) to predict global zooplankton biomass distribution.
The study covered a 10-year period (2008-2018) and analyzed 466,872 images from 3,549 stations worldwide.
Boosted Regression Trees (BRTs) were used to model the relationship between zooplankton biomass and environmental variables.

title: Global Zooplankton Biomass Distribution
text:
Key Findings

Global Biomass Estimate: The total zooplankton biomass in the upper 500m of the ocean was estimated at 0.403 Pg with an estimated 0.229 PgC for the epipelagic layer (0-200 m) and 0.173 PgC for the mesopelagic layer (200-500 m).



Distribution map of the predicted minimum global biomass between 0 and 500m (Figure 11 of the paper).


Dominant Groups:

Copepoda: 35.7% of total biomass
Eumalacostraca: 26.6%
Rhizaria: 16.4%

Spatial Distribution:

Highest biomass values were found around 60°N and 55°S.
Lowest biomass was predicted in oceanic gyres and the Arctic (north of 80°N).
An increase in biomass was observed around the equator.

title: Global Zooplankton Biomass Distribution
text:
Implications

This study provides a new method for estimating global zooplankton biomass using in situ imaging and machine learning.
The findings emphasize the importance of using non-intrusive sampling methods to accurately assess the biomass of fragile organisms like Rhizaria which has been underestimated in previous net-based studies.
The results can be valuable for improving global biogeochemical models and understanding the role of zooplankton in marine ecosystems and the carbon cycle.

title: Global Zooplankton Biomass Distribution
text:
Perspectives

Continued use of imaging systems like UVP5 and UVP6 to expand the dataset and improve predictions.
Focus on sampling underrepresented areas, particularly in polar regions during winter.
Integration of data from multiple imaging systems to cover a wider size spectrum of zooplankton.

title: Zooplanktonic silhouettes
text:
About this illustration
These silhouettes of zooplanktonic organisms were done for personal presentations and used by other scientists for their own presentations. On the top left is the silhouette of a Cavolinia (Gastropoda). The other two organisms are copepods with the top one being an Oithona and the lower one a Calanoida.

title: Atmospheric Response to Antarctic Coastal Polynyas
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was created as the graphical abstract for the research article Atmospheric Response to Antarctic Coastal Polynyas published in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres by Matthias Noël and colleagues at LOCEAN-IPSL (Sorbonne Université, Paris). The paper investigates the atmospheric response to Antarctic coastal polynyas using high-resolution atmospheric modeling.
The schematic illustrates the key atmospheric processes triggered by the opening of a coastal polynya in Antarctica.

title: Forms and colors of plankton - Zooplankton
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was done in the context of a project called “Forms and colors of plankton” built in collaboration with Sakina-Dorothée Ayata, Associate Professor at Sorbonne University and at LOCEAN (Laboratory of Oceanography and Climate), and holder of a scientific mediation chair at the French University Institute.
This project was done in partnership with the Parisian Porte Dorée Tropical Aquarium, the Paris Academy and the Patay kindergarten school. Two sessions were done at the school with all the classes. The first one was done in January 2025 with exercises sheets designed for this project and focused on coloring and counting. The second session in May 2025 was done using news exercise sheets around counting. A board game was specifically designed for this project, using 3D printed organisms. Bonus coloring sheets were distributed.

 

Other illustrations were done to illustrate these processes:

title: Zooplankton and marine particles sampling instruments
text:
Plankton has been traditionally sampled using nets and niskin bottles illustrated in the traditional plankton sampling gear.
Marine Snow Catcher is one of the instrument that can be used to sample sinking marine particles.
More recent instruments include imaging systems such as the Underwater Vision Profiler 5 (Picheral et al., 2010) and 6, its more recent version. These in situ imaging system were designed to detect, measure and quantify the distribution of zooplankton organisms and marine particles. The images captured by these instruments are then saved on the Ecotaxa platform and through a software called Zooprocess, we have access to 42 morphological descriptors such as size, transparency, complexity, ect. Note that the relative size of the instruments are not respected here.

  

See below some examples of images of organisms captured by the UVP5:

title: Shrimp vocabulary
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was created in collaboration with teachers in the LOV laboratory for students in the Science de la Mer master affiliated with Sorbonne Université as well as for the summer school DIMAPLAN organised at the LOV’s teaching facility.

title: Website logo
text:
About this illustration
This logo was created for the first UVP User Meeting organised at the Laboratoire d’Océanographie de Villefranche, Villefranche-sur-Mer, France and online, on the 15th and 16th September 2022. The visual codes from the laboratory’s logo were kept in mind to obtain this logo.

title: Biography
text:
Welcome to my research and illustration portfolio!


I am currently a CNRS postdoctoral researcher at the LOCEAN laboratory in Paris, working on the spatial distribution and diversity of zooplankton and phytoplankton using quantitative imaging and machine learning techniques.


My research integrates environmental and biological data to investigate spatial distribution of zooplankton and phytoplankton as well as their role in the biological carbon pump.











Skills



Statistical Habitat Modeling


Data Analysis and Programming (R, Python, Matlab)


Scientific Illustration and Visual Communication


Quantitative in situ imaging (UVP, ZooScan, Planktoscope)





Interests



Marine Plankton Ecology


Biodiversity and Ecosystem Functioning


Science Outreach and Public Engagement


Urban sketching and plein air art

title: Study of the Effects of the UV Filter Benzophenone-3 on the Lipid Metabolism of European Sea Bass
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was created as a visual support for Manon Lefèvre, a PhD student (and very good friend) who participated in the french academic competition “My Thesis in 180 Seconds” where PhD students present their thesis in a very short 3 minutes. You can watch her regional performance in this video.
Here is a presentation of her work and context for this illustration.
Manon is a PhD student in ecotoxicology at the University of Le Havre Normandy and conducts her research at the SEBIO laboratory. She studies the effects of benzophenone-3 (BP-3), a UV filter commonly used in sunscreens, on the lipid metabolism of the European sea bass (Dicentrarchus labrax). Her objective is to better understand the mechanisms of action of this pollutant on fish physiology and to evaluate the risks it poses to marine ecosystems. For Manon, participating in the “My Thesis in 180 Seconds” competition is an opportunity to share her research with the general public and raise awareness about the impact of emerging pollutants on aquatic ecosystems. SEBIO – Environmental Stressors and BIOmonitoring of aquatic environments (University of Le Havre Normandy | University of Reims Champagne-Ardenne | INERIS)

title: Century-scale carbon sequestration flux throughout the ocean by the biological pump
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was created as a graphical abstract for a CNRS press release La séquestration de carbone par la pompe biologique n’est pas l’apanage de l’océan profond published on 30, November 2023.
This press release presented the scientific paper Century-scale carbon sequestration
flux throughout the ocean by the biological pump published in September 2022 by Ricour et al. We based this illustration on the first figure of the article.
An interactive presentation of the paper is available here.

title: Responses of shallow-water Arctic benthic communities to climate change
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was created as a graphical abstract for Dr. Anais Lebrun’s PhD defense on Responses of shallow-water Arctic benthic communities to climate change.
Disclaimer: I did not illustrate the benthic organisms in this illustration. They had been previously used in the PhD manuscript, and we kept them for this illustration to keep a cohesive visual approach.

title: Responses of shallow-water Arctic benthic communities to climate change
text:
Chapter images
To help with the visual cohesiveness, we created circular images that she used throughout her oral presentation for the different chapters.

title: Image-based global analysis of the biological carbon pump
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was created as a graphical abstract for my PhD Thesis Image-based global analysis of the biological carbon pump.
The images of aggregates, zooplankton organisms and fecal pellets were taken from the Underwater Vision Profiler 5 dataset.

title: Forms and colors of plankton - Phytoplankton
text:
About this illustration
This illustration was done in the context of a project called “Forms and colors of plankton” built in collaboration with Sakina-Dorothée Ayata, Associate Professor at Sorbonne University and at LOCEAN (Laboratory of Oceanography and Climate), and holder of a scientific mediation chair at the French University Institute.
This project was done in partnership with the Parisian Porte Dorée Tropical Aquarium, the Paris Academy and the Patay kindergarten school. Children were given a presentation about planktonic organisms as well as multiple exercises to work on forms and colors using phytoplanktonic organisms as examples for square, triangle, circle and rectangle.

title: Website logo
text:
About this illustration
This logo was created with my scientific studies in mind with the wave representing marine studies, the network for data management and machine learning and my initials.

title: Welcome to My Coding Corner!
text: Here you’ll find a collection of projects covering various coding topics. Feel free to explore the posts below, use the category filters to find specific topics, or sort by date to see my latest work. Happy coding!

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text: This dataset is published on SEANOE and corresponds to the data paper Long-term plankton and environmental monitoring dataset from the marine protected area of the Iroise Marine Natural Park (2010–2023) in the Iroise Sea, North Atlantic (Earth Syst. Sci. Data, 2025).

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Dataset Overview
This 14-year monitoring effort (2010–2023) combines phytoplankton and zooplankton observations with environmental measurements from the Iroise Marine Natural Park, France’s first marine protected area. The dataset represents a unique, spatially and temporally resolved record of plankton communities in a region characterized by complex oceanography and significant ecological and economic value.


Sampling zone in the Iroise Marine Natural Park (Figure 1 of the paper).

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
What’s Included
Phytoplankton data (2010–2022): 785 samples containing 573 unique taxa identified by microscopy at species or genus level. All transect samples were processed by the same experienced taxonomist to ensure consistency across the 13-year period.
Zooplankton data (2010–2023): 650 samples digitized using the ZooScan imaging system, yielding 655,930 individual organism images. These were automatically classified and then validated by expert annotators, resulting in 103 taxonomic and morphological groups with both abundance and biovolume measurements.
Environmental parameters: Temperature and salinity measured at surface and bottom depths across all sampling sites, providing context for interpreting biological patterns.
Sampling design: Two coastal-to-offshore transects (northern transect B with 7 stations, southern transect D with 6 stations) plus three coastal stations (Molène, Sein, Douarnenez). Seasonal sampling increased from three to four times yearly starting in 2017.


Examples of planktonic organisms imaged by the ZooScan for the 20 most abundant taxa (Figure 3 of the paper).

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Key Findings
Phytoplankton distribution: Remarkable temporal and spatial variability, with peak abundances (>2 × 10⁶ cells L⁻¹) occurring in 2011 and 2022 for transect B, and 2016 and 2021–2022 for transect D. No consistent coastal-to-offshore gradient was evident when data were temporally averaged, likely because the seasonal Ushant thermal front’s spatial effects are obscured by seasonal averaging.
Zooplankton patterns: Clear coastal-to-offshore gradients with decreasing abundances seaward. Coastal stations (especially B1 and D1) consistently showed highest concentrations, reaching up to 8 × 10³ individuals m⁻³. Copepods and Branchiopods dominated coastal waters, while Mollusca showed inverse gradients with higher offshore proportions. Overall, community structure remained relatively stable across the 13-year period.

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Why This Matters
This dataset addresses a significant gap in plankton monitoring for the Iroise region. While other French coastal monitoring programs exist (SOMLIT, REPHY, PELGAS), none provide comparable spatial and temporal coverage of both plankton groups simultaneously within a protected marine area.
The data are particularly valuable because they combine traditional microscopy (phytoplankton) with modern imaging technology (zooplankton), demonstrating how complementary approaches can be integrated and shared. This is especially important given recent findings of declining small pelagic fish body sizes across French waters—understanding their primary food resource (plankton) is essential for fisheries management and ecosystem conservation.

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Technical Strengths

Taxonomic consistency: Phytoplankton identification by the same taxonomist ensures reliability across the time series
High taxonomic resolution: 573 phytoplankton taxa and detailed zooplankton morphological measurements enable trait-based analyses
Individual-level data: Complete zooplankton images are publicly accessible via EcoTaxa, allowing future morphometric and machine learning applications
FAIR compliance: All code and data follow FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable)

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Data Structure
The dataset comprises three tables: one for phytoplankton abundances with environmental context, one for zooplankton abundances and biovolumes with environmental data, and one providing complete taxonomic hierarchies with WoRMS identifiers for unambiguous species identification.

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Broader Context
The Iroise Marine Natural Park occupies a unique position at the intersection of the English Channel and Atlantic Ocean, shaped by the seasonal Ushant thermal front that creates distinct coastal and offshore habitats. Beyond its ecological significance, the region supports France’s historic sardine fishery centered in Douarnenez. Long-term plankton monitoring is thus critical for both biodiversity conservation and preserving the economic and cultural heritage that led to the park’s designation.

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Perspectives
The dataset opens opportunities for investigating seasonal patterns in plankton community composition, modeling ecosystem responses to environmental gradients, and developing machine learning applications for plankton classification. The individual zooplankton images are particularly valuable for future trait-based studies linking morphological diversity to ecosystem functioning and carbon cycling.

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Overview
14-year monitoring (2010–2023) of phytoplankton and zooplankton communities in the Iroise Marine Natural Park, France’s first marine protected area. Combines traditional microscopy with ZooScan imaging and environmental measurements across two coastal-to-offshore transects and three coastal stations.


Sampling zone in the Iroise Marine Natural Park (Figure 1 of the paper).

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text: Dataset published on SEANOE | Paper in Earth Syst. Sci. Data

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Overview
14-year monitoring (2010–2023) of phytoplankton and zooplankton communities in the Iroise Marine Natural Park, France’s first marine protected area. Combines traditional microscopy with ZooScan imaging and environmental measurements across two coastal-to-offshore transects and three coastal stations.


Sampling zone in the Iroise Marine Natural Park (Figure 1 of the paper).

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
What’s Included

Phytoplankton: 785 samples, 573 taxa identified to species/genus level
Zooplankton: 650 samples, 655,930 individual images, 103 taxonomic/morphological groups with abundances and biovolumes
Environment: Temperature and salinity at surface and bottom



Examples of planktonic organisms imaged by the ZooScan for the 20 most abundant taxa (Figure 3 of the paper).

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Key Findings
Remarkable temporal and spatial variability in phytoplankton. Clear coastal-offshore zooplankton gradients with highest concentrations in coastal stations. Community structure remained stable across the study period.

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Why This Matters
This dataset addresses a significant gap in plankton monitoring for the Iroise region. While other French coastal monitoring programs exist (SOMLIT, REPHY, PELGAS), none provide comparable spatial and temporal coverage of both plankton groups simultaneously within a protected marine area.
Combines phytoplankton and zooplankton with high taxonomic resolution, enabling trait-based analyses. Critical for understanding ecosystem responses to environmental change and supporting fisheries management in a region central to France’s sardine industry.

title: Long-term Plankton and Environmental Monitoring Dataset from the Iroise Marine Natural Park
text:
Perspectives
The dataset opens opportunities for investigating seasonal patterns in plankton community composition, modeling ecosystem responses to environmental gradients, and developing machine learning applications for plankton classification. The individual zooplankton images are particularly valuable for future trait-based studies linking morphological diversity to ecosystem functioning and carbon cycling.

title: Predicting Plankton Diversity with Machine Learning
text:
Can operational ocean models (CMEMS) predict plankton diversity in the Iroise Marine Natural Park? This analysis combines 14 years of in situ monitoring with machine learning to identify environmental drivers of community structure.
Code and its description available on GitHub
These explorations were done in the context of the NECCTON.

title: Predicting Plankton Diversity with Machine Learning
text:
Can operational ocean models (CMEMS) predict plankton diversity in the Iroise Marine Natural Park? This analysis combines 14 years of in situ monitoring with machine learning to identify environmental drivers of community structure.
Code and its description available on GitHub
These explorations were done in the context of the NECCTON.

title: Predicting Plankton Diversity with Machine Learning
text:
Questions
Which oceanographic variables best explain plankton diversity? How do environmental drivers differ between phytoplankton and zooplankton? Can operational models predict local diversity? What is the relative importance of physical versus biogeochemical drivers?

title: Predicting Plankton Diversity with Machine Learning
text:
Methods
Diversity indices were computed from zooplankton and phytoplankton abundance tables, grouped by station and date. In situ diversity metrics were merged with CMEMS data by matching station and sampling date. Analyses were conducted at multiple taxonomic levels (classes, species and genus) and depths (surface and bottom) to capture community patterns across different scales.
XGBoost models were trained to predict each diversity index from oceanographic predictors. Model performance was evaluated using standard machine learning metrics including RMSE, R², and mean absolute error. Variable importance scores were extracted to rank environmental drivers.
